posts.post_content:
Wow, what is wrong with this guy's oracle text?  
...  
Okay, I guess it's because if it was as long as he's not attacking, you could declare a bunch of attackers, him last, and the rest wouldn't tap.  
...  
Still, though, that's pretty ridiculous.

posts.post_content: Because Vigilance would involve giving them an ability, and the ability as printed didn't give them the "doesn't tap to attack" ability. The Oracle is written with the philosophy of trying to stick as closely as possible to the original behavior of the card.
posts.html:
Because Vigilance would involve giving them an ability, and the ability as printed didn't give them the "doesn't tap to attack" ability. The Oracle is written with the philosophy of trying to stick as closely as possible to the original behavior of the card.

posts.post_content: The oracle text is a lot more confusing than it needs to be. Posted By: Moleland (6/8/2011 2:28:05 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content: The problem that makes the Oracle text so wacky is that Johan becomes an attacker at the same time everyone else does, and it's during that same time that creatures that are attacking get tapped. Once you know whether or not Johan attacked, it's too late to futz with not-vigilance, so you have to give the rules some lead time with the lock-in clause.
posts.html:
The problem that makes the Oracle text so wacky is that Johan becomes an attacker at the same time everyone else does, and it's during that same time that creatures that are attacking get tapped. Once you know whether or not Johan attacked, it's too late to futz with not-vigilance, so you have to give the rules some lead time with the lock-in clause.

Yeah, his Oracle text seems like a bit much.
